channel.title: Client.java (PI) rep++
channel.description:
How can I fix this, so I can acctually read it properly and add some texts?
REP++ FOR HELP.
[URL=http://img683.imageshack.us/i/clienta.png/][IMG]http://img683.imageshack.us/img683/5346/clienta.png[/img][/URL]

item.title: Client.java (PI) rep++
item.dc:creator: @Jddogg9 Jddogg9
item.description:
@Jddogg9 wrote:

Go to format, and un-check “Word wrap”. Same shit happened to me.

Read full topic

item.title: Client.java (PI) rep++
item.dc:creator: @frozon566 frozon566
item.description:
@frozon566 wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:7, topic:380575”][quote author=Christiaan link=topic=476402.msg3483918#msg3483918 date=1296409195]
I’m not new to Java, i tried it some time ago but i prefer the old notepad.
However, if you are new to java, Notepad++ would be better to learn it.

On Topic: maybe if you maximize your notepad, it shows correct.
[/quote]
Coding with plain Notepad is about the dumbest idea I have ever heard. You will have the worst conventions known to man; I don’t even know how you could read anything.[/quote]
eaither use notepad++ or eclipse. eclipse i recommend because its specifically made for java programming and its pretty simple once u get used to it.

notepad++
http://download.cnet.com/Notepad/3000-2352_4-10327521.html

eclipse
http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/

Read full topic

item.title: Client.java (PI) rep++
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

[quote=“Christiaan, post:4, topic:380575”]If Notepad++ does the same, you could use that instead.
Im always using the old Notepad, so idk if it does.[/quote]

i also use N++ , it helps alot with IF switches as it shows if you have as many { as you have }
i really suggest it if you’re new to coding java

item.title: Client.java (PI) rep++
item.dc:creator: @Christiaan Christiaan
item.description:
@Christiaan wrote:

You could download JAD java-decompiler to decompile the .class file, this gives you the .java file, that .java file will be written in the usual way.
